review: I own this Apple TV v3, and I own a Roku LT.  Both are great devices, with similar function.The Roku works great for Netflix and Pandora.  I love both of those services, and Roku delivers.  Roku is also expandable - there are hundreds of other "channels".  But in general all those other Roku channels stink.  Sorry "other channel" guys (including you, huge online retail store named after a south american river).The Apple TV is a little more closed, but what it provides is excellent.  I can still use Netflix with the Apple TV, and plus I can stream all my music, movies, and  TV shows to the device with nearly zero setup.  "It just works" is very true.  I also love the wireless remote display capability - it is easy to "stream" my Mac's display, or my iPhone display, or my iPad display to my TV.  Again, it just works.  Roku?  I do technical work all day for my job.  I don't also want to do it all night at my house.In all, I love both Apple TV and Roku.  Roku is now on the back burner due to the great features of the Apple TV.

review: The Apple TV MD199LL/A seems to be a great little unit, but I'm posting to warn potential buyers who have older TVs.  My TV is a 62", rear-projection, DLP with a fantastic HD picture and HDMI inputs (Toshiba 62HMX84), but WHAT my TV is really doesn't matter.  What does matter is when it was manufactured.  When some of my content wouldn't play with an error about HDCP, I did some digging and found that in 2004, the HDCP standards (copy protection for HD shows/movies) were put in place (my TV is HD, but not HDCP compliant).When you use your AppleTV to play Netflix, Movie Previews, HD movies or TV you purchased from iTunes, they all require HDCP or you will get an error message on your screen and cannot watch them.  If you search for an answer, a lot of people will tell you to power off and power on both the AppleTV (or other HDMI device) and the TV...and this will work for some people, but if your TV is a little older, it may not be compatible at all.I didn't know I had this issue for a long time because my HD TiVO has component outputs that go to the TV (instead of HDMI) and Netflix will play fine HD from the TiVO, but this AppleTV has ONLY HDMI.I love the AppleTV and I'm going to keep it, but I can only play movies that are standard definition from iTunes, home-made movies or that I have ripped from DVD (removes copy protection as part of the process).  I will have to wait until I upgrade my TV to enjoy most of the other features of the AppleTV (renting movies from iTunes, Netflix, Previews, etc).  If you have nothing but time on your hands, I've also read that you can remove the protection from iTunes downloaded HD material, but you still can't get around the streaming content like Netflix or iTunes movie rental.
